questions.question: Most cardiovascular developments occur between which weeks of gestation?
questions.rationale: Cardiogenesis begins around 3 weeks, but most major development occurs between 4–7 weeks.

questions.question: Function of the foramen ovale in a fetus:
questions.rationale: The foramen ovale allows blood to bypass the lungs via right-to-left shunting.

questions.question: At birth, which statement is true?
options: Systemic resistance and pulmonary resistance fall
Gas exchange shifts from placenta to lung
Systemic resistance falls, pulmonary resistance rises
Systemic resistance and pulmonary resistance rise
questions.rationale: At birth, the infant shifts from placental oxygenation to pulmonary gas exchange.

questions.question: When does systemic vascular resistance increase in infants?
questions.rationale: Removal of the low-resistance placenta doubles systemic vascular resistance.

questions.question: Which event triggers acyanotic CHF?
questions.rationale: Left-to-right shunts increase pulmonary blood flow, leading to CHF.

questions.question: Older child with uncorrected septal defect develops cyanosis due to:
questions.rationale: Pulmonary vascular resistance increases over time, reversing the shunt.

questions.question: Which congenital defects are linked to trisomy 13, 18, and Down syndrome?
questions.rationale: Trisomies and Down syndrome commonly include VSD and PDA.

questions.question: Continuous machine-type murmur, bounding pulses, CHF in infant =
questions.rationale: PDA causes continuous machine-like murmur and bounding pulses.

questions.question: Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur between 2nd–3rd intercostal spaces, fixed split S2 =
questions.rationale: ASD causes systolic ejection murmur with fixed split of S2.

questions.question: Loud holosystolic murmur at left lower sternal border radiating to neck =
questions.rationale: VSD produces harsh holosystolic murmur, often with thrill.

questions.question: Location of COA:
options: Between subclavian origin and ductus arteriosus
questions.rationale: Classic COA is just distal to subclavian origin, near ductus arteriosus.

questions.question: Classic signs of COA:
questions.rationale: COA = upper extremity HTN, weak/absent femoral pulses, systolic murmur.

questions.question: Initial manifestation of COA in neonates:
questions.rationale: Newborns with COA usually present with CHF.

questions.question: Compensatory mechanism in Tetralogy of Fallot:
questions.rationale: Squatting ↑ systemic resistance, reduces right-to-left shunt.

questions.question: Small PDA infant likely presents with:
questions.rationale: Small PDA is often asymptomatic with intermittent murmur.

questions.question: Most common cause of neonatal sustained HTN:
questions.rationale: Renal artery stenosis is most common in newborn sustained HTN.

questions.question: Transposition of great vessels:
questions.rationale: In TGA, aorta connects to RV and pulmonary artery to LV.

questions.question: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return:
questions.rationale: All pulmonary veins connect abnormally to RA/systemic veins.

questions.question: Systolic ejection murmur at right upper sternal border radiating to neck =
questions.rationale: Aortic stenosis causes harsh ejection murmur at RUSB.

questions.question: Systolic ejection click at upper LSB with thrill:
questions.rationale: Pulmonary stenosis causes systolic ejection click + thrill at LSB.

questions.question: Single vessel supplying both systemic + pulmonary circulation =
questions.rationale: Truncus arteriosus = failure of embryonic truncus to separate.

questions.question: Suggested BP for 9-year-old child:
questions.rationale: Normal for 8–9 years = ~104/55.

questions.question: Congenital defects associated with maternal rubella (select all):
questions.rationale: A, C, D: PS, PDA, COA are associated with maternal rubella.

questions.question: Diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease (select all):
questions.rationale: A, B, C, D, E: All listed are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

questions.question: ABPM statements true (select all):
questions.rationale: A, B, C, D: ABPM monitors BP for 24h, identifies white coat and masked HTN, and detects high-risk organ damage.

questions.question: Matching: ASD, Foramen ovale, Septum secundum, Ostium primum, Bulbus cordis
options: Gap between septum primum and secundum
questions.rationale: 26. ASD → Abnormal communication between atria; 27. Foramen ovale → Allows right-to-left shunting; 28. Septum secundum → Causes atrial separation; 29. Ostium primum → Gap between septum primum and secundum; 30. Bulbus cordis → Conal portion of ventricular septum.
